Award.AwardTitle: Student Paper Competition Travel Support for the 2011 IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium in Baltimore, MD on June 5-10, 2011

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this activity is to provide partial travel support for 7-10 students from U.S. universities who are participating in the student paper competition at the 2011 IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium (IMS). The IMS is the annual meeting of the Microwave Theory and Techniques Society (MTT-S) of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc. (IEEE). The IMS is also the major international symposium in the microwave field and a focus of research results in wireless telecommunications. The 2011 IMS will be held in Baltimore, MD, USA on June 5-10, 2011.

Intellectual Merit: The main impact is primarily educational, as the travel support allows students' participation in IMS 2011. The activity helps to bring together the most original and impacting research done by graduate students over the past year in the field of RF and microwave engineering and provides these students with a venue for highlighting this work and share it with the broader community.


Broader Impacts: This activity helps with supporting the work of the microwave community's brightest students, to allow them to interact with the world's leading
researchers in microwave engineering at the premier technical conference in the field, and to strengthen the broader technical community by assisting future researchers and leaders in traveling to and attending the symposium.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to support student travel to the 2011 IEEE Microwave Symposium in Baltimore Maryland, for those students presenting papers in the symposium student paper competition. The student paper competition highlights outstanding research being done by students worldwide in the area of RF and microwave engineering. Papers for the student competition are selected through a rigorous review process by the symposium technical program review committee, and the final competition typically consists of 24 finalists.

During the symposium, finalists in the student paper competition present their work in both oral and poster format. This permits them to discuss their work with a panel of judges who review each of the papers in the compeition. After reviewing all papers, the judges score and rank the papers according to their originality, importance, and potential impact on the field. With this input, papers are selected for first prize (one paper), second prize (two papers), third prize (three papers) and honorable mention (four papers).

For the student paper competition at the 2011 IEEE MIcrowave Sympsoium, NSF funds were requested to support student travel. After the grant application was made, but before the NSF funds became available, the conference chairman budgeted funds from the symposium general operating budget to support student travel. Consequently, the NSF funds were unused and have been returned to NSF.


Last Modified: 09/19/2012
Modified by: Robert M Weikle
